newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian students march, Socialists ponder move.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian students march, Socialists ponder move.

text.p: Bulgarian students marched through central Sofia on Saturday, blocking traffic to press their campaign against the ruling Socialists.
To chants of "Victory", hundreds of boisterous university students in two separate marches paraded through the heart of the capital.
The processions of ragtag students beat drums, banged cymbals, and blew whistles and horns as they made their way past government ministries.
They stopped before each government office to boo, chant "Mafia, Mafia, Mafia" and then set off again. Gangs of students charged ahead with Bulgarian flags flying, blocking traffic for 15 minutes.
Residents watched from windows, often flashing "V" signs or joining in the chants and songs. Despite 27 days of protesting in bitter cold, the students remain in high spirits.
Students and the main opposition Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) were staging three marches and an evening mass rally in Sofia on Saturday to keep up their anti-government protests.
The campaign has piled pressure on dispirited and divided Socialists to quit and hold elections nearly two years ahead of schedule.

While the Balkan country sinks further into economic chaos, the Socialists -- the former communists -- have been struggling to form a new government. They have until Tuesday to present a new cabinet to parliament and face a vote of confidence.
Nationwide strikes and protests have intensified over the past week in an effort to force the Socialists to abandon their efforts to form a government and to call elections.
Some 1,000 UDF supporters blocked the main southern road and rail links to Greece for a fourth day. UDF said it would reinforce the blockades and offered people free rides from Sofia.
About 100 riot police stood nearby while tyres burned in the highway. Pop music blared, protesters pinned red carnations on police and a festive mood prevailed despite the cold.
President Petar Stoyanov met central bank governor Lyubomir Filipov on Saturday to discuss a letter from International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Michel Camdessus.

Camdessus said the IMF was ready to help Bulgaria through its economic crisis as soon as a valid government was in place. He urged Stoyanov to impress on all political parties the high social cost of delay.
The Socialists will hold a special meeting of parliamentary deputies, coalition partners and the Supreme Council of the Socialist Party on Sunday to chart their next move.
Interior Minister Nikolai Dobrev, who received a mandate to form a government, has appeared half-hearted in his efforts and has offered several times to stand aside, or even to return the mandate.
He told Reuters in an interview on Friday he was willing to accept a coalition cabinet formed under Stoyanov.
"I don't mind if it is formed under the leadership of the president," he said. "I am ready to return my mandate if such a government is formed."
But he then postponed a meeting with Stoyanov, apparently under pressure from hardliners in his party. He said later the Socialists needed more time to talk with other parties.
The Socialists, elected for a four-year term in 1994, have overseen a caretaker cabinet since December when Zhan Videnov resigned as prime minister.
